In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is the solution:

```julia
function wrap_string(words, text_width::Int = 10)
    str = ""
    
    for word in words
        if length(str) + length(word) > text_width
            println(str)
            str = word
        elseif length(str) == 0
            str = word
        else
            str *= " $(word)"
        end
    end

    println(str)
end
```
This function `wrap_string` takes an array of words and a width for the text. It iterates over each word in the words array, and if adding that word to the current string would exceed the maximum width, it prints out the current string (which is reset afterwards), and starts a new string with just this word. If no string has been printed yet (`str` length is 0), it simply adds the first word to the string. Otherwise, it appends a space followed by the next word to the current string.

Here's an example usage of this function:

```julia
words = ["This", "is", "a", "test", "string"]
wrap_string(words)
```
The output would be:

```text
This is a test 
string
```
